Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: It’s Wednesday afternoon, and my headset is glued to my ears as I rattle off another pitch about home insurance. My sales numbers are soaring this week—my manager even gave me a thumbs-up as I passed her desk. I should feel proud, but my phone buzzes with a text from my stepdad: “Haven’t heard from you in a while. Everything okay?” I realize I haven’t checked in since last weekend. My mom always says it means a lot to them when I reach out, even just a quick hello. But every minute I spend texting is a minute I’m not making calls, and I’m so close to smashing my sales target. I stare at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, torn between the warmth of family and the thrill of professional success. The guilt gnaws at me—am I letting them down if I wait until after work? Or am I risking my momentum at the job if I pause now? My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations, feeling stretched thin between two worlds that both want more of me.
